instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.P3V3S5_EN_L: What is P3V3S5_EN_L? P3V3S5_EN_L is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is low. .
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.P3V42_G3H: What is P3V42_G3H? P3V42_G3H is a typo of PP3V42_G3H.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that came in with no power but green light on the charger. Front side of the board looks clean but back side has plenty of pubes, food, and nasty human junk, but I don't see any liquid damage. PP3V42 present, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> present, but <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> are going crazy. On pins 1 and 2 of <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> I measure them and PPVRTC fluctuates between 3.3 volts and 3.47 volts and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumps from 0 volts to 3.3 volts. Does this mean that <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> has issues or could it be something else?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Oh yeah I should prob add that this is a replacement board has a sharpie mark on top of each coil, port, and anything silver.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: is <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_ENTRIP</SIGNAL> jumping too????

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Actually no on pin 6 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> it's a constant 0.772 volts which I'm guessing is definitely lower than it should be. It's the same on <RESISTOR>R7272</RESISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR>. <SIGNAL>PP3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> is not present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> present??? What is the exact voltage on  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Update: Found some liquid damage it was very hard to see but it was <CAPACITOR>C4617</CAPACITOR>, L4600, and <CHIP>U3311</CHIP> but none of those have to do with this I would guess?

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is present but 0.082 volts

threads.message: Actually revise that <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is 3.42 volts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: So <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is present.....What about <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL>....... CHeck after and before <RESISTOR>R7941</RESISTOR>....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Ok so now <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is present BUT it is power cycling. This has happened to me with <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> too where I will plug in a known good charger and it will stay constant then after unplugging it once and plugging it back in it will jump between 0 and 3.3.... Pin 1 of 7941 jumps from 0 to 3.3v. Pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7941</RESISTOR> for <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> is 3.4 but also jumping from 0 to 3.4 continuously....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> is suspect. Also check all rails for shorts.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Checked each power rail, no short to ground on any of the rails. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is also pulsing between 3.3 and 4.96, so replace <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> and check back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Replaced <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> and still no dice. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> all still pulsing between 0 and their appropriate voltages

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Starting to think there's a blown trace or internal short. Idk what the deal might be also noticed on the back of the board for Firewire and the other ports there were components loose and corroded. I wonder if someone messed with this board before or if it was assembled by someone who was careless.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: PPVRTC should be stable if 3V42 rail is present, so start there. <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> makes PPVRTC from PP3V42.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Ok now I have created a bigger problem :/ I tried a new <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> just to be safe, and when I did, somehow the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS</SIGNAL> pin quite literally burned the trace. I ran a jumper from <CAPACITOR>C7272</CAPACITOR> to the pad and then properly soldered the <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> back on and checked each pad. However, now I still have a green light, but <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is only .23 volts. It is not shorted to ground, but now I have another problem because I made a stupid mistake. Where would I go from here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Resistance to GND on PPBUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Well looks like maybe a short now wasn't yesterday. Looks like resistance is 0.4 ohms At best but it does drop to zero.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Fix the short, probably at that BBQ around the 51125

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Haha I love me some KC barbecue but not on logic boards! I checked the 51125 area and re did the jumper and replaced the chip. I can say I definitely got a lot better at running that wire and soldering that chip lol, but the short is still 0.27 volts. I did notice around the fuse got hot, so I replaced the PPBUS fuse, but still no dice. If I inject voltage how much should I inject? I don't want to kill the board if it isn't already dead.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Voltage doesn't matter, look at the current draw. At 1 Amp something should start heating up.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 27696"]I did notice around the fuse got hot, so I replaced the PPBUS fuse, but still no dice.[/QUOTE]

How could the fuse short the power to ground? Think before you replace :)

Inject Amperage, more voltage will not help heat things up. Best to start at a low voltage like 1V and put the Amperage at 1A and start going up until you feel things starting heating up. Only increase the voltage if you can't inject more amps because the voltage limit is reached
I can not recommend putting the voltage at something high (>1.7V) in case its leaking away into a circuit that requires a lower voltage so you don't blow it up though

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Uhm, you cannot inject Amps, only voltage. The resulting current is the voltage * resistance.....You can only current limit and that just limits the voltage until the desired current is flowing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: My bad for the wording, I was trying to refer to the current limit. Thanks for the clarification

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Ok gotcha guys. I have a Siglent supply just need to find good probes to solder on and inject voltage as the probes that came with it are kinda janky. Haven't gotten to do anything with board last few days because slammed with all the boring iPhone iPad and Mac repairs. We need a second tech to do that easy shit so I can focus solely on this stuff :/

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Ok so stripped the wire for the crap probes we got so I could use them to inject voltage. I Solder red to ground black to PPBUS pad for the fuse. I start at one volt and one amp of power and nothing heats up but if I increase voltage it remains constant at 0.79 volts with one amp of power? Does that mean my power supply is messed up or is that bad?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message:
[QUOTE="JohnB8812, post: 27742"]Ok so stripped the wire for the crap probes we got so I could use them to inject voltage. I Solder red to ground black to PPBUS pad for the fuse. I start at one volt and one amp of power and nothing heats up but if I increase voltage it remains constant at 0.79 volts with one amp of power? Does that mean my power supply is messed up or is that bad?[/QUOTE]

?? Red is usually positive and Black Negative

Did you just inject a negative amount of voltage? Not a lot of chips are going to like that.
How are your wires connected up?

0.79 volt @ 1Amp is alright. Your supply is not malfunctioning given that either your voltage is set at 0.79 OR your current limit is set at 1Amp.
If nothing is heating up you can increase the current limit until something is.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Ok yeah Smiba you’re right on the power supply I didn’t see the positivie and negative my probes were backwards. I will retry that again tomorrow lmao makes a lot more sense now. I figured it wasn’t the aupply because I can easily inject voltage into iPhones with the battery probes I have for them so that’s why I wondered if maybe I had had bad probes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message:
If you have the probes swapped on the supply as well it doesn't matter. They're both the same piece of copper wire.
Just make sure whatever probe is ground on the supply is going to ground on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Ok gotcha. Will retry that again tomorrow

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: You injected voltage with wrong polarity? I dunno man this board is probably pretty toasted by now :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Fuck :( how does the wrong polarity destroy it just curious? Want to avoid doing that ever again even by accident

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message:
Power will flow to the circuit in the wrong direction, polarized capacitors won't like this and a lot of diodes in IC's will mess up and possibly destroy parts of the IC.

Since you applied a current limit and the voltage was not very high you might have some luck but I woudn't be surprised some more things are broken now. Just try and see if we can solve it, this time with the polarity right.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Ok I understand. With the right polarity, red on PPBUS black on ground, I get zero amp draw no matter what voltage I inject. I think it's probably fucked now :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message:
Possibly. Having a total 0 amperage draw sounds unlikely though, are we talking about a low amperage draw (0.01A - 0.1A @ 12V) or just nothing at all?

Green light on the charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Green light yes PP3V42 still there, but I mean literally 0.01 then drops to 0. Only gets 0.01 if I pump up the voltage to like 5 or 7

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message:
Doesn't sound too unlogical, the System is in S5 and on a really low voltage so most ICs aren't even working.

The charging light is still there so hope is not all lost.
Just for the sake of clarity, While just running the board from the charger right now. What is the voltage of <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: PPBUS is 0.25 votls. PPVRTC <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> are not there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message:
Alright I will have to warn you this is most likely a rabbit hole and unfixable, so if you have other things to do I'd drop this one.

If you feel like continuing

Voltage of:
<SIGNAL>P3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP5V1_CHGR_VDD</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPCHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> jumping around
threads.message: Yeah the customer actually has purchased a new computer from us, so he’s all set. I think I’m gonna use this as a donor (for whatever is still good on it) just because I think you’re right it’s gonna be a nightmare at this point. I appreciate all your guys’s help with this one learned a TON from this board as this is is the first I’ve ever had with no power like that I’ve only had sensor issue Macs, no backlight Macs and easy JTAG removal ones so this was definitely my first true challenge repair. Next time, I’m just gonna have to be a little more careful with a problem like this, but I definitely think this one will help for the long term.
